poem_title: AN ODE, Humbly Inscrib'd to the QUEEN. ON THE Glorious Success OF Her MAJESTY's Arms, 1706. Written in Imitation of Spencer's Style.
author: Matthew Prior
poem_alt_title: Written in Imitation of Spencer's Style .

lines.line_text: Great  govern'd Antient ,
And sent his Conqu'ring Bands to Foreign Wars;
Abroad when Dreaded, and Belov'd at Home,
He saw his Fame encreasing with his Years;
, Great Bard (so Fate ordain'd) arose;
And Bold, as were his Countrymen in Fight,
Snatch'd their fair Actions from degrading Prose,
And set their Battels in Eternal Light:
High as their Trumpets Tune His Lyre he strung;
And with his Prince's Arms He moraliz'd his Song.
When bright  rul'd  State,
Widely distributing Her high Commands;
And boldly Wise, and fortunately Great,
Freed the glad Nations from Tyrannick Bands;
An equal Genius was in  found:
To the high Theme He match'd his Noble Lays:
He travell'd  o'er on Fairy Ground,
In Mystic Notes to Sing his Monarch's Praise:
Reciting wond'rous Truths in pleasing Dreams,
He deck'd  Head with  Beams.

stanzas.stanza_text:
When bright  rul'd  State,
Widely distributing Her high Commands;
And boldly Wise, and fortunately Great,
Freed the glad Nations from Tyrannick Bands;
An equal Genius was in  found:
To the high Theme He match'd his Noble Lays:
He travell'd  o'er on Fairy Ground,
In Mystic Notes to Sing his Monarch's Praise:
Reciting wond'rous Truths in pleasing Dreams,
He deck'd  Head with  Beams.

lines.line_text: But, Greatest ! while Thy Arms pursue
Paths of Renown, and climb Ascents of Fame,
Which nor , nor  knew;
What Poet shall be found to sing Thy Name?
What Numbers shall record, what Tongue shall say
Thy Wars on Land, Thy Triumphs on the Main?
O Fairest Model of Imperial Sway!
What Equal Pen shall write Thy wond'rous Reign?
Who shall Attempts and Feats of Arms rehearse,
Not yet by Story told, nor parallel'd by Verse?

stanzas.stanza_text:
But, Greatest ! while Thy Arms pursue
Paths of Renown, and climb Ascents of Fame,
Which nor , nor  knew;
What Poet shall be found to sing Thy Name?
What Numbers shall record, what Tongue shall say
Thy Wars on Land, Thy Triumphs on the Main?
O Fairest Model of Imperial Sway!
What Equal Pen shall write Thy wond'rous Reign?
Who shall Attempts and Feats of Arms rehearse,
Not yet by Story told, nor parallel'd by Verse?

lines.line_text: Me all too mean for such a Task I weet:
Yet if the Sovereign Lady deigns to Smile,
I'll follow  with impetuous Heat,
And cloath the Verse in  Native Style.
By these Examples rightly taught to sing,
And Smit with Pleasure of my Country's Praise,
Stretching the Plumes of an uncommon Wing,
High as  I my Flight will raise:
And latest Times shall in my Numbers read
Immortal Fame, and  hardy Deed.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Me all too mean for such a Task I weet:
Yet if the Sovereign Lady deigns to Smile,
I'll follow  with impetuous Heat,
And cloath the Verse in  Native Style.
By these Examples rightly taught to sing,
And Smit with Pleasure of my Country's Praise,
Stretching the Plumes of an uncommon Wing,
High as  I my Flight will raise:
And latest Times shall in my Numbers read
Immortal Fame, and  hardy Deed.

lines.line_text: As the strong Eagle in the silent Wood,
Mindless of warlike Rage, and hostile Care,
Plays round the rocky Cliff, or crystal Flood;
'Till by  high Behests call'd out to War,
And charg'd with Thunder of his angry King,
His Bosom with the vengeful Message glows:
Upward the Noble Bird directs his Wing;
And tow'ring round his Master's Earth-born Foes,
Swift He collects his fatal Stock of Ire;
Lifts his fierce Talon high, and darts the forked Fire.
Sedate and calm thus Victor  sate,
Shaded with Laurels, in his Native Land;
'Till  calls Him from his soft Retreat,
And gives Her Second Thunder to his Hand.
Then leaving sweet Repose, and gentle Ease,
With ardent Speed He seeks the distant Foe:
Marching o'er Hills and Vales, o'er Rocks and Seas,
He meditates, and strikes the wond'rous Blow.
Our Thought flies slower than Our General's Fame:
Grasps He the Bolt? (We ask) when He has hurl'd the Flame.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Sedate and calm thus Victor  sate,
Shaded with Laurels, in his Native Land;
'Till  calls Him from his soft Retreat,
And gives Her Second Thunder to his Hand.
Then leaving sweet Repose, and gentle Ease,
With ardent Speed He seeks the distant Foe:
Marching o'er Hills and Vales, o'er Rocks and Seas,
He meditates, and strikes the wond'rous Blow.
Our Thought flies slower than Our General's Fame:
Grasps He the Bolt? (We ask) when He has hurl'd the Flame.

lines.line_text: When fierce  on  spacious Plain
Did from afar the  Chief behold;
Betwixt Despair, and Rage, and Hope, and Pain,
Something within his warring Bosom roll'd:
He views that Fav'rite of Indulgent Fame,
Whom whilom He had met on  Shoar:
Too well, alas! the Man He knows the same,
Whose Prowess there repell'd the  Pow'r;
And sent Them trembling thro' the frighted Lands,
Swift as the Whirlwind drives  scatter'd Sands.

stanzas.stanza_text:
When fierce  on  spacious Plain
Did from afar the  Chief behold;
Betwixt Despair, and Rage, and Hope, and Pain,
Something within his warring Bosom roll'd:
He views that Fav'rite of Indulgent Fame,
Whom whilom He had met on  Shoar:
Too well, alas! the Man He knows the same,
Whose Prowess there repell'd the  Pow'r;
And sent Them trembling thro' the frighted Lands,
Swift as the Whirlwind drives  scatter'd Sands.

lines.line_text: His former Losses He forgets to grieve;
Absolves his Fate, if with a kinder Ray
It now would shine, and only give Him leave
To Balance the Account of  Day.
So the fell Lion in the lonely Glade,
His Side still smarting with the Hunter's Spear,
Tho' deeply wounded, no way yet dismay'd,
Roars terrible, and meditates new War;
In sullen Fury traverses the Plain,
To find the vent'rous Foe, and Battel Him again.

stanzas.stanza_text:
His former Losses He forgets to grieve;
Absolves his Fate, if with a kinder Ray
It now would shine, and only give Him leave
To Balance the Account of  Day.
So the fell Lion in the lonely Glade,
His Side still smarting with the Hunter's Spear,
Tho' deeply wounded, no way yet dismay'd,
Roars terrible, and meditates new War;
In sullen Fury traverses the Plain,
To find the vent'rous Foe, and Battel Him again.

lines.line_text: Misguided Prince! no longer urge Thy Fate,
Nor tempt the Hero to unequal War;
Fam'd in Misfortune, and in Ruin Great,
Confess the Force of  stronger Star.
Those Laurel Groves (the Merits of thy Youth)
Which Thou from  didst greatly gain,
While bold Assertor of resistless Truth,
Thy Sword did Godlike Liberty maintain,
Must from thy Brow their falling Honors shed;
And their transplanted Wreaths must deck a worthier Head.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Misguided Prince! no longer urge Thy Fate,
Nor tempt the Hero to unequal War;
Fam'd in Misfortune, and in Ruin Great,
Confess the Force of  stronger Star.
Those Laurel Groves (the Merits of thy Youth)
Which Thou from  didst greatly gain,
While bold Assertor of resistless Truth,
Thy Sword did Godlike Liberty maintain,
Must from thy Brow their falling Honors shed;
And their transplanted Wreaths must deck a worthier Head.

lines.line_text: Yet cease the Ways of Providence to blame,
And Human Faults with Human Grief confess:
'Tis Thou art chang'd; while Heav'n is still the same:
From Thy ill Councils date Thy ill Success.
Impartial Justice holds Her equal Scales;
'Till stronger Virtue does the Weight incline:
If over Thee thy glorious Foe prevails;
He now Defends the Cause, that once was Thine.
Righteous the War, the Champion shall subdue;
For  great Handmaid , must  Decrees pursue.
Hark! the dire Trumpets sound their shrill Alarms:
, branch'd from the renown'd ,
Hoary in War, and bent beneath his Arms,
His Glorious Sword with Dauntless Courage draws.
When anxious  mourn'd her parting Lord,
And all of  that was Mortal Dy'd;
The faithful Hero had receiv'd This Sword
From His expiring Master's much-lov'd Side.
Oft from it's fatal Ire has  flown,
Where-e'er Great  led, or  and  run.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Hark! the dire Trumpets sound their shrill Alarms:
, branch'd from the renown'd ,
Hoary in War, and bent beneath his Arms,
His Glorious Sword with Dauntless Courage draws.
When anxious  mourn'd her parting Lord,
And all of  that was Mortal Dy'd;
The faithful Hero had receiv'd This Sword
From His expiring Master's much-lov'd Side.
Oft from it's fatal Ire has  flown,
Where-e'er Great  led, or  and  run.

lines.line_text: But brandish'd high, in an ill-omen'd Hour
To Thee, proud , behold thy justest Fear,
The Master Sword, Disposer of thy Power:
'Tis That which  gave the  Peer.
He took the Gift: Nor ever will I sheath
This Steel, (so  high Behests ordain)
The General said, unless by Glorious Death
Absolv'd, 'till Conquest has confirm'd Your Reign.
Returns like these Our Mistress bids us make,
When from a foreign Prince a Gift Her  take.

stanzas.stanza_text:
But brandish'd high, in an ill-omen'd Hour
To Thee, proud , behold thy justest Fear,
The Master Sword, Disposer of thy Power:
'Tis That which  gave the  Peer.
He took the Gift: Nor ever will I sheath
This Steel, (so  high Behests ordain)
The General said, unless by Glorious Death
Absolv'd, 'till Conquest has confirm'd Your Reign.
Returns like these Our Mistress bids us make,
When from a foreign Prince a Gift Her  take.

lines.line_text: And now fierce  rushes on her Foes,
Her Force augmented by the  Bands:
So  Stream, increas'd by Mountain Snows,
Rolls with new Fury down thro'  Lands.
Like two great Rocks against the raging Tide,
(If Virtue's Force with Nature's We compare)
Unmov'd the Two united Chiefs abide,
Sustain the Impulse, and receive the War.
Round their firm Sides in vain the Tempest beats;
And still the foaming Wave with lessen'd Pow'r retreats.

stanzas.stanza_text:
And now fierce  rushes on her Foes,
Her Force augmented by the  Bands:
So  Stream, increas'd by Mountain Snows,
Rolls with new Fury down thro'  Lands.
Like two great Rocks against the raging Tide,
(If Virtue's Force with Nature's We compare)
Unmov'd the Two united Chiefs abide,
Sustain the Impulse, and receive the War.
Round their firm Sides in vain the Tempest beats;
And still the foaming Wave with lessen'd Pow'r retreats.

lines.line_text: The Rage dispers'd, the Glorious Pair advance,
With mingl'd Anger, and collected Might,
To turn the War, and tell aggressing ,
How  Sons and  Friends can fight.
On Conquest fix'd, and covetous of Fame,
Behold Them rushing thro' the  Host.
Thro' standing Corn so runs the sudden Flame,
Or Eastern Winds along  Coast.
They deal their Terrors to the adverse Nation:
Pale Death attends their Arms, and ghastly Desolation.

stanzas.stanza_text:
The Rage dispers'd, the Glorious Pair advance,
With mingl'd Anger, and collected Might,
To turn the War, and tell aggressing ,
How  Sons and  Friends can fight.
On Conquest fix'd, and covetous of Fame,
Behold Them rushing thro' the  Host.
Thro' standing Corn so runs the sudden Flame,
Or Eastern Winds along  Coast.
They deal their Terrors to the adverse Nation:
Pale Death attends their Arms, and ghastly Desolation.

lines.line_text: But while with fiercest Ire  glows,
And  rather Hopes than Fears Her Fate;
While  presses Her afflicted Foes;
What Horror damps the Strong, and quells the Great?
Whence look the Soldiers Cheeks dismay'd and pale?
Erst ever dreadful, know They now to dread?
The Hostile Troops, I ween, almost prevail;
And the Pursuers only not recede.
Alas! their lessen'd Rage proclaims their Grief!
For anxious, lo! They croud around their falling Chief!
I thank Thee, Fate, exclaims the fierce ;
Let  Trumpet grateful I's sound:
I saw Him fall, their Thunderbolt of War:
Ever to Vengeance sacred be the Ground
Vain Wish! short Joy! the Hero mounts again
In greater Glory, and with fuller Light:
The Ev'ning Star so falls into the Main,
To rise at Morn more prevalently bright.
He rises safe: but near, too near his Side,
A good Man's grievous Loss, a faithful Servant dy'd.

stanzas.stanza_text:
I thank Thee, Fate, exclaims the fierce ;
Let  Trumpet grateful I's sound:
I saw Him fall, their Thunderbolt of War: 
Ever to Vengeance sacred be the Ground 
Vain Wish! short Joy! the Hero mounts again
In greater Glory, and with fuller Light:
The Ev'ning Star so falls into the Main,
To rise at Morn more prevalently bright.
He rises safe: but near, too near his Side,
A good Man's grievous Loss, a faithful Servant dy'd.

lines.line_text: Propitious ! the Battel is regain'd:
The Foe with lessen'd Wrath disputes the Field:
The  fights, by fav'ring Gods sustain'd:
Freedom must live; and lawless Power must yield.
Vain now the Tales which fab'ling Poets tell,
That wav'ring  still desires to rove!
In  Camp the Goddess knows to dwell:
Long as the Hero's Life remains her Love.
Again  flies: again the Duke pursues:
And on  Plains He  Fame renews.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Propitious ! the Battel is regain'd:
The Foe with lessen'd Wrath disputes the Field:
The  fights, by fav'ring Gods sustain'd:
Freedom must live; and lawless Power must yield.
Vain now the Tales which fab'ling Poets tell,
That wav'ring  still desires to rove!
In  Camp the Goddess knows to dwell:
Long as the Hero's Life remains her Love.
Again  flies: again the Duke pursues:
And on  Plains He  Fame renews.

lines.line_text: Great Thanks, O Captain great in Arms! receive
From thy Triumphant Country's public Voice:
Thy Country greater Thanks can only give
To , to Her who made those Arms Her Choice.
Recording , and  Toils,
We dreaded lest Thou should'st those Toils repeat:
We view'd the Palace charg'd with  Spoils;
And in those Spoils We thought thy Praise compleat:
For never , We deem'd, nor  Knight,
In Characters like these did e'er his Acts indite.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Great Thanks, O Captain great in Arms! receive
From thy Triumphant Country's public Voice:
Thy Country greater Thanks can only give
To , to Her who made those Arms Her Choice.
Recording , and  Toils,
We dreaded lest Thou should'st those Toils repeat:
We view'd the Palace charg'd with  Spoils;
And in those Spoils We thought thy Praise compleat:
For never , We deem'd, nor  Knight,
In Characters like these did e'er his Acts indite.

lines.line_text: Yet mindless still of Ease, Thy Virtue flies
A Pitch to Old and Modern Times unknown:
Those goodly Deeds which We so highly prize,
Imperfect seem, great Chief, to Thee alone.
Those Heights, where  Virtue might have staid,
And on the Subject World look'd safely down,
By  pass'd, the Props and Steps were made,
Sublimer yet to raise his Queen's Renown:
Still gaining more, still slighting what He gain'd,
Nought done the Hero deem'd, while ought undone remain'd.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Yet mindless still of Ease, Thy Virtue flies
A Pitch to Old and Modern Times unknown:
Those goodly Deeds which We so highly prize,
Imperfect seem, great Chief, to Thee alone.
Those Heights, where  Virtue might have staid,
And on the Subject World look'd safely down,
By  pass'd, the Props and Steps were made,
Sublimer yet to raise his Queen's Renown:
Still gaining more, still slighting what He gain'd,
Nought done the Hero deem'd, while ought undone remain'd.

lines.line_text: When swift-wing'd  told the mighty ,
How lessen'd from the Field  was fled;
He wept the Swiftness of the Champion's Fall;
And thus the Royal Treaty-Breaker said:
And lives He yet, the Great, the Lost ,
Ruin to , in the Name of Friend?
Tell Me, how far has Fortune been severe?
Has the Foe's Glory, or our Grief an End?
Remains there, of the Fifty Thousand lost,
To save our threaten'd Realm, or guard our shatter'd Coast?

stanzas.stanza_text:
When swift-wing'd  told the mighty ,
How lessen'd from the Field  was fled;
He wept the Swiftness of the Champion's Fall;
And thus the Royal Treaty-Breaker said:
And lives He yet, the Great, the Lost ,
Ruin to , in the Name of Friend?
Tell Me, how far has Fortune been severe?
Has the Foe's Glory, or our Grief an End?
Remains there, of the Fifty Thousand lost,
To save our threaten'd Realm, or guard our shatter'd Coast?

lines.line_text: To the close Rock the frighted Raven flies,
Soon as the rising Eagle cuts the Air:
The shaggy Wolf unseen and trembling lyes,
When the hoarse Roar proclaims the Lion near.
Ill-starr'd did We our Forts and Lines forsake,
To dare our  Foes to open Fight:
Our Conquest We by Stratagem should make:
Our Triumph had been founded in our Flight.
'Tis Our's, by Craft and by Surprize to gain:
'Tis Their's, to meet in Arms, and Battel in the Plain.

stanzas.stanza_text:
To the close Rock the frighted Raven flies,
Soon as the rising Eagle cuts the Air:
The shaggy Wolf unseen and trembling lyes,
When the hoarse Roar proclaims the Lion near.
Ill-starr'd did We our Forts and Lines forsake,
To dare our  Foes to open Fight:
Our Conquest We by Stratagem should make:
Our Triumph had been founded in our Flight.
'Tis Our's, by Craft and by Surprize to gain:
'Tis Their's, to meet in Arms, and Battel in the Plain.

lines.line_text: The ancient Father of this Hostile Brood,
Their boasted , undaunted snatch'd his Gods
From burning , and  red with Blood,
And fix'd on Silver  his dire Abodes;
And this be , He said, the Seat
By Heav'n ordain'd, My Sons, Your lasting Place:
Superior here to all the Bolts of Fate
Live, mindful of the Author of your Race,
Whom neither , nor War, nor Want, nor Flame,
Nor Great Arm, nor  Rage could tame.

Live, mindful of the Author of your Race,
Whom neither , nor War, nor Want, nor Flame,

lines.line_text: Their  hence, and  Off-spring flow:
Hence , dreadful with his Sable Shield,
, to  Pow'r Eternal Foe,
And , fam'd in Council, or in Field:
Hence , Great to Settle or Dethrone,
And , and , Terrors of the Sea:
Hence  Sons, o'er Land and Ocean known,
, and  Warring Progeny:
Hence the long Roll which  should conceal:
For, oh! Who vanquish'd, loves the Victor's Fame to tell?

lines.line_text: Envy'd , sturdy as the Oak,
Which on her Mountain-Top She proudly bears,
Eludes the Ax, and sprouts against the Stroke;
Strong from her Wounds, and greater by her Wars.
And as Those Teeth, which  sow'd in Earth,
Produc'd new Youth, and furnish'd fresh Supplies:
So with young Vigor, and succeeding Birth,
Her Losses more than recompens'd arise;
And ev'ry Age She with a Race is Crown'd,
For Letters more Polite, in Battels more Renown'd.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Envy'd , sturdy as the Oak,
Which on her Mountain-Top She proudly bears,
Eludes the Ax, and sprouts against the Stroke;
Strong from her Wounds, and greater by her Wars.
And as Those Teeth, which  sow'd in Earth,
Produc'd new Youth, and furnish'd fresh Supplies:
So with young Vigor, and succeeding Birth,
Her Losses more than recompens'd arise;
And ev'ry Age She with a Race is Crown'd,
For Letters more Polite, in Battels more Renown'd.

lines.line_text: Obstinate Pow'r, whom Nothing can repel;
Not the fierce , nor the cruel ,
Nor deep Impression of the  Steel,
Nor  Force amass'd by envious ,
Nor  on universal Sway intent,
Oft breaking Leagues, and oft renewing Wars,
Nor (frequent Bane of weaken'd Government)
Their own intestine Feuds, and mutual Jars;
Those Feuds and Jars, in which I trusted more,
Than in My Troops, and Fleets, and all the  Pow'r.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Obstinate Pow'r, whom Nothing can repel;
Not the fierce , nor the cruel ,
Nor deep Impression of the  Steel,
Nor  Force amass'd by envious ,
Nor  on universal Sway intent,
Oft breaking Leagues, and oft renewing Wars,
Nor (frequent Bane of weaken'd Government)
Their own intestine Feuds, and mutual Jars;
Those Feuds and Jars, in which I trusted more,
Than in My Troops, and Fleets, and all the  Pow'r.

lines.line_text: To fruitful , or fair  Gate
What Tidings shall the Messenger convey?
Shall the loud Herald our Success relate,
Or mitred Priest appoint the Solemn Day?
Alas! my Praises They no more must Sing;
They to my Statue now must Bow no more:
Broken, repuls'd is their Immortal King:
Fall'n, fall'n for ever is the  Pow'r
The  is Master of the War:
Earth She has freed by Arms, and vanquish'd Heav'n by Pray'r.

lines.line_text: While thus the ruin'd Foe's Despair commends
Thy Council and Thy Deed, Victorious queen,
What shall Thy Subjects say, and what Thy Friends?
How shall Thy Triumphs in Our Joy be seen?
Oh! daign to let the Eldest of the
Recite  Great, and  Free:
Oh! with her Sister  let her join
To raise, Great , the Monument to Thee;
To Thee, of all our Good the Sacred Spring;
To Thee, our dearest Dread; to Thee, our softer .

lines.line_text: Let  sav'd the Column high erect,
Than  higher, or than ;
Where sembling Art may carve the fair Effect,
And full Atchievement of Thy great Designs.
In a calm Heav'n, and a serener Air,
Sublime the  shall on the Summit stand,
From Danger far, as far remov'd from Fear,
And pointing down to Earth Her dread Command.
All Winds, all Storms that threaten Human Woe,
Shall sink beneath Her Feet, and spread their Rage below.

In a calm Heav'n, and a serener Air,
Sublime the  shall on the Summit stand,

lines.line_text: There Fleets shall strive by Winds and Waters tost;
'Till the young  on  Strand,
Great as  on the  Coast,
Shall fix his Foot: and This, be This the Land,
Great , where I for ever will remain
(The Empire's other Hope shall say) and here
Vanquish'd, Intomb'd I'll lye, or Crown'd I'll Reign
O Virtue, to thy  Mother dear!
Like the fam'd  suffer and abide;
For  is Thine, I ween, as  was His Guide.

lines.line_text: There, in Eternal Characters engrav'd,
, and , and ,
Their Force destroy'd, their Privileges sav'd,
Shall  Terrors, and Her Mercies own:
, from th'Usurper  Arms retriev'd,
Shall with new Life and grateful Joy appear,
Numb'ring the Wonders which That Youth atchiev'd,
Whom  clad in Arms, and sent to War;
Whom  sent to claim  Throne;
And made Him more than King, in calling Him Her Son.

lines.line_text: There  pleas'd, by  glorious Field
Rolling, shall bid his Eastern Waves declare
sav'd by  ample Shield,
And bleeding  afflicted by her Spear:
Shall bid Them mention , on that Shore
Leading his Islanders, renown'd in Arms,
Thro' Climes, where never  Chief before
Or pitch'd his Camp, or sounded his Alarms:
Shall bid Them bless the , who made his Streams
Glorious as those of , and safe as those of .

stanzas.stanza_text:
There  pleas'd, by  glorious Field
Rolling, shall bid his Eastern Waves declare
sav'd by  ample Shield,
And bleeding  afflicted by her Spear:
Shall bid Them mention , on that Shore
Leading his Islanders, renown'd in Arms,
Thro' Climes, where never  Chief before
Or pitch'd his Camp, or sounded his Alarms:
Shall bid Them bless the , who made his Streams
Glorious as those of , and safe as those of .

lines.line_text: , clad with Fields, and crown'd with Tow'rs,
With decent Joy shall her Deliv'rer meet;
Shall own Thy Arms, Great , and bless Thy Pow'rs,
Laying the Keys beneath Thy Subject's Feet.
, by Plenty made the Home of War,
Shall weep her Crime, and bow to  restor'd;
With double Vows shall bless Thy happy Care,
In having drawn, and having sheath'd the Sword.
From these their Sister Provinces shall know
How  supports a Friend, and how forgives a Foe.

, clad with Fields, and crown'd with Tow'rs,

Shall own Thy Arms, Great , and bless Thy Pow'rs,

, by Plenty made the Home of War,

lines.line_text: Bright Swords, and crested Helms, and pointed Spears
In artful Piles around the Work shall lye;
And Shields indented deep in ancient Wars,
Blazon'd with Signs of  Heraldry;
And Standards with distinguish'd Honors bright,
Marks of high Pow'r and National Command,
Which Sons, and  bore in Fight,
Or gave to , or  Hand:
Great Spoils, which  must to  yield,
From  Battel sav'd, to grace  Field.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Bright Swords, and crested Helms, and pointed Spears
In artful Piles around the Work shall lye;
And Shields indented deep in ancient Wars,
Blazon'd with Signs of  Heraldry;
And Standards with distinguish'd Honors bright,
Marks of high Pow'r and National Command,
Which Sons, and  bore in Fight,
Or gave to , or  Hand:
Great Spoils, which  must to  yield,
From  Battel sav'd, to grace  Field.

lines.line_text: And as fine Art the Spaces may dispose,
The knowing Thought and curious Eye shall see
Thy Emblem, Gracious , the  Rose,
Type of sweet Rule, and gentle Majesty:
The  Thistle, whom no Hostile Hand
Unhurt too rudely may provoke, I ween;
Harp, Device of Her Command,
And Parent of Her Mirth, shall there be seen:
Thy vanquish'd Lillies, , decay'd and torn,
Shall with disorder'd Pomp the lasting Work adorn.

stanzas.stanza_text:
And as fine Art the Spaces may dispose,
The knowing Thought and curious Eye shall see
Thy Emblem, Gracious , the  Rose,
Type of sweet Rule, and gentle Majesty:
The  Thistle, whom no Hostile Hand
Unhurt too rudely may provoke, I ween;
Harp, Device of Her Command,
And Parent of Her Mirth, shall there be seen:
Thy vanquish'd Lillies, , decay'd and torn,
Shall with disorder'd Pomp the lasting Work adorn.

lines.line_text: Beneath, Great , oh! very far beneath,
Near to the Ground, and on the humble Base,
To save Her self from Darkness, and from Death,
That  desires the last, the lowest Place;
Who tho' unmeet, yet touch'd the trembling String;
For the fair Fame of  and  Land,
Who durst of War and Martial Fury Sing:
And when Thy Will, and when Thy Subject's Hand
Had quell'd those Wars, and bid that Fury cease;
Hangs up her grateful Harp to Conquest, and to Peace.
